title: Linear independence
content:
According to the definition in [Lang] p. 129: "A subset S of a module M is said to be linearly independent (over [the ring] A) if whenever we have a linear combination ∑x ∈S axx which is equal to 0, then ax=0 for all x∈S." This definition does not care for the finiteness of the set S (because the definition of a linear combination in [Lang] p.129 does already assure that only a finite number of coefficients can be 0 in the sum). Our definition ~ df-lininds does also neither claim that the subset must be finite, nor that almost all coefficients within the linear combination are 0. If this is required, it must be explicitly stated as precondition in the corresponding theorems.

Usually, the linear independence is defined for vector spaces, see Wikipedia ("Linear independence", 15-Apr-2019, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_independence ): "In the theory of vector spaces, a set of vectors is said to be linearly dependent if at least one of the vectors in the set can be defined as a linear combination of the others; if no vector in the set can be written in this way, then the vectors are said to be linearly independent." Furthermore, "In order to allow the number of linearly independent vectors in a vector space to be countably infinite, it is useful to define linear dependence as follows. More generally, let V be a vector space over a field K, and let {vi | i∈I} be a family of elements of V. The family is linearly dependent over K if there exists a finite family {aj | j∈J} of elements of K, all nonzero, such that ∑j∈J ajvj=0. A set X of elements of V is linearly independent if the corresponding family{x}x∈X is linearly independent".
Remark 1: There are already definitions of (linearly) independent families ( ~ df-lindf ) and (linearly) independent sets ( ~ df-linds ). These definitions are based on the principle "of vectors, no nonzero multiple of which can be expressed as a linear combination of other elements" or (see ~ lbsind2 ) "every element is not in the span of the remainder of the [[set]". The equivalence of the definitions ~ df-linds and ~ df-lininds for (linear) independence for (left) modules is shown in ~ lindslininds .
Remark 2: Subsets of the base set of a (left) module are linearly dependent if they are not linearly independent (see ~ df-lindeps ) or, according to Wikipedia, "if at least one of the vectors in the set can be defined as a linear combination of the others", see ~ islindeps2 . The reversed implication is not valid for arbitrary modules (but for arbitrary vector spaces), because it requires a division by a coefficient. Therefore, the definition of Wikipedia is equivalent to our definition for (left) vector spaces (see ~ isldepslvec2 ) and not for (left) modules in general.

axiom df-lininds(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3) {
  |- wceq(clininds, copab(s0, s1, wa(wcel(cv(s0), cpw(cfv(cbs, cv(s1)))), wral(s2, co(cfv(cbs, cfv(csca, cv(s1))), cmap, cv(s0)), wi(wa(wbr(cv(s2), cfsupp, cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, cv(s1)))), wceq(co(cv(s2), cfv(clinc, cv(s1)), cv(s0)), cfv(c0g, cv(s1)))), wral(s3, cv(s0), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), cv(s3)), cfv(c0g, cfv(csca, cv(s1))))))))))
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
}

  ancoms(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cfn), wb(wbr(c2, clininds, c0), wa(wcel(c2, cpw(c3)), wral(s0, co(c4, cmap, c2), wi(wceq(co(cv(s0), cfv(clinc, c0), c2), c5), wral(s1, c2, wceq(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c6)))))))

  diff.hs1.c(c1)

thm islindeps(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7) {
  ‚ä¢ ((c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà P(c3))‚Üí(c2[linDepS]c0 ‚Üî ‚àÉ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),(s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6 ‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5)))))
  ‚ä£ c3 =(Base ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c6 =(0 ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c7 =(Scalar ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c4 =(Base ` c7)
  ‚ä£ c5 =(0 ` c7)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c0)

} = {
  3bitrd((c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà P(c3)), c2[linDepS]c0, ‚àÉ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),(s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6 ‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5))), ¬¨ c2[linIndS]c0, ¬¨ ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))
  ancoms(c0 ‚àà c1, c2 ‚àà P(c3), (c2[linDepS]c0 ‚Üî ¬¨ c2[linIndS]c0))
  lindepsnlininds(c2, P(c3), c0, c1)
  notbid((c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà P(c3)), c2[linIndS]c0, ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))
  bitrd((c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà P(c3)), c2[linIndS]c0, ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))), (c2 ‚àà P(c3)‚àß ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)))))
  ancoms(c0 ‚àà c1, c2 ‚àà P(c3), (c2[linIndS]c0 ‚Üî(c2 ‚àà P(c3)‚àß ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))))
  islininds(s0, s1, c2, P(c3), c0, c1, c3, c4, c5, c6, c7)
  adantl(c0 ‚àà c1, c2 ‚àà P(c3), ((c2 ‚àà P(c3)‚àß ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))‚Üî ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)))))
  bicomd(c2 ‚àà P(c3), (c2 ‚àà P(c3)‚àß ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)))), ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))
  ibar(c2 ‚àà P(c3), ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))
  a1i((c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà P(c3)), (¬¨ ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)))‚Üî ‚àÉ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),(s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6 ‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5)))))
  bitr3i(¬¨ ‚àÄ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))), ‚àÉ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2),(s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6 ‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5))), ‚àÉ(s0 ‚àà(c4[‚Ü¶]c2), ¬¨((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))))
  rexnal(s0, (c4[‚Ü¶]c2), ((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)))
  rexbii(s0, (c4[‚Ü¶]c2), ¬¨((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)), (s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6 ‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5)))
  3bitr4i(¬¨((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚Üí ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)), (s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6 ‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5)), ((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚àß ¬¨ ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5)), ((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6)‚àß ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5)))
  anbi2i((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6), ¬¨ ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5), ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5))
  bitr2i(¬¨ ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5), ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5), ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2, ¬¨(s0 ` s1)= c5))

  pm4.61((s0[finSupp]c5 ‚àß(s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6), ‚àÄ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)= c5))
  df-3an(s0[finSupp]c5, (s0[(linC ` c0)]c2)= c6, ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,(s0 ` s1)‚â† c5))

thm lindslinindsimp2(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, clmod)), wi(wa(wss(c0, cfv(cbs, c2)), wral(s0, c0, wral(s1, cdif(c3, csn(c4)), wn(wcel(co(cv(s1), cfv(cvsca, c2), cv(s0)), cfv(cfv(clspn, c2), cdif(c0, csn(cv(s0))))))))), wa(wcel(c0, cpw(cfv(cbs, c2))), wral(s2, co(c3, cmap, c0), wi(wa(wbr(cv(s2), cfsupp, c4), wceq(co(cv(s2), cfv(clinc, c2), c0), c5)), wral(s3, c0, wceq(cfv(cv(s2), cv(s3)), c4)))))))
  -| wceq(c6, cfv(csca, c2))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cbs, c6))

blocks.name: lindslininds
blocks.content: Equivalence of definitions ~ df-linds and ~ df-lininds for (linear) independence for (left) modules. (Contributed by AV, 26-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm lindslininds(class c0, class c1, class c2) {

blocks.content: The empty set is always a linearly independent subset. (Contributed by AV, 13-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 27-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: el0ldep
blocks.content: A set containing the zero element of a module is always linearly dependent, if the underlying ring has at least two elements. (Contributed by AV, 13-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 27-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: el0ldepsnzr
blocks.content: A set containing the zero element of a module over a nonzero ring is always linearly dependent. (Contributed by AV, 14-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 27-Apr-2019.)

blocks.name: lindsrng01
blocks.content: Any subset of a module is always linearly independent if the underlying ring has at most one element. Since the underlying ring cannot be the empty set (see ~ lmodsn0 ), this means that the underlying ring has only one element, so it is a zero ring. (Contributed by AV, 14-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 27-Apr-2019.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: snlindsntor
blocks.content: A singleton is linearly independent iff it does not contain a torsion element. According to Wikipedia ("Torsion (algebra)", 15-Apr-2019, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torsion_(algebra) ): "An element m of a module M over a ring R is called a _torsion element_ of the module if there exists a regular element r of the ring (an element that is neither a left nor a right zero divisor) that annihilates m, i.e., ` ( r .x. m ) = 0 ` . In an integral domain (a commutative ring without zero divisors), every nonzero element is regular, so a torsion element of a module over an integral domain is one annihilated by a nonzero element of the integral domain." Analogously, the definition in [Lang] p. 147 states that "An element x of [a module] E [over a ring R] is called a _torsion element_ if there exists ` a e. R ` , ` a =/= 0 ` , such that ` a .x. x = 0 ` . This definition includes the zero element of the module. Some authors, however, exclude the zero element from the definition of torsion elements. (Contributed by AV, 14-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 27-Apr-2019.)

blocks.name: ldepspr
blocks.content: If a vector is a scalar multiple of another vector, the (unordered pair containing the) two vectors are linearly dependent. (Contributed by AV, 16-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 27-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:
thm ldepspr(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, class c8, class c9) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, clmod), w3a(wcel(c1, c2), wcel(c3, c2), wne(c1, c3))), wi(wa(wcel(c4, c5), wceq(c1, co(c4, c6, c3))), wbr(cpr(c1, c3), clindeps, c0)))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
  -| wceq(c7, cfv(csca, c0))

blocks.content: Property 3 of a specially modified restriction of a linear combination in a vector space. (Contributed by AV, 18-May-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: isldepslvec2
blocks.content: Alternative definition of being a linearly dependent subset of a (left) vector space. In this case, the reverse implication of ~ islindeps2 holds, so that both definitions are equivalent (see theorem 1.6 in [Roman] p. 46 and the note in [Roman] p. 112: if a nontrivial linear combination of elements (where not all of the coefficients are 0) in an R-vector space is 0, then and only then each of the elements is a linear combination of the others. (Contributed by AV, 30-Apr-2019.) (Proof shortened by AV, 30-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:

  -| wceq(c2, cfv(cbs, c0))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(c0g, c0))
  -| wceq(c6, cfv(csca, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cbs, c6))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(c0g, c6))

  -| diffsc(s0, c3)

  -| diffsc(s0, c6)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)

  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c4)
  -| diffsc(s1, c5)
  -| diffsc(s1, c6)
} = {
  impbid(wa(wcel(c0, clvec), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wrex(s0, c1, wrex(s1, co(c3, cmap, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0)))), wa(wbr(cv(s1), cfsupp, c4), wceq(co(cv(s1), cfv(clinc, c0), cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0)))), cv(s0))))), wbr(c1, clindeps, c0))

  adantr(wcel(c0, clvec), wcel(c1, cpw(c2)), wcel(c0, clmod))
  simpr(wcel(c0, clvec), wcel(c1, cpw(c2)))
  adantr(wcel(c0, clvec), wcel(c1, cpw(c2)), wcel(c6, cnzr))
  syl(wcel(c0, clvec), wcel(c6, cnzr), wcel(c6, cdr))
  drngnzr(c6)
  islindeps2(s0, s1, c0, c1, c2, c6, c3, c4, c5)
  sylbid(wa(wcel(c0, clvec), wcel(c1, cpw(c2))), wbr(c1, clindeps, c0), wrex(s0, c1, wrex(s1, co(c3, cmap, cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0)))), wa(wbr(cv(s1), cfsupp, c4), wceq(co(cv(s1), cfv(clinc, c0), cdif(c1, csn(cv(s0)))), cv(s0))))), wrex(hs0, co(c3, cmap, c1), w3a(wbr(cv(hs0), cfsupp, c4), wceq(co(cv(hs0), cfv(clinc, c0), c1), c5), wrex(s0, c1, wne(cfv(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), c4)))))
  islindeps(hs0, s0, c0, clvec, c1, c2, c3, c4, c5, c6)

blocks.name: lindssnlvec
blocks.content: A singleton not containing the zero element of a vector space is always linearly independent. (Contributed by AV, 16-Apr-2019.) (Revised by AV, 28-Apr-2019.)
